update.description:
This is a draft of the design for a simulation validation tool for Gazebo.

We would like to have this tool stable and ready to be used by October so it can collect data for a HAPTIX milestone in November.
update.title: Simulation validation tool

content.raw: If you think I can contribute something to the discussion, I'm happy to join in. Even restricting the problem to, for example, dynamics or sensory simulation does not seem to make it easy. I do think that jumping in and trying to quantify differences in even an arbitrary way is helpful to see the landscape of problems. I can suggest some data sets (both numerically verified and physically obtained) to start from.
content.html: If you think I can contribute something to the discussion, I'm happy to join in. Even restricting the problem to, for example, dynamics or sensory simulation does not seem to make it easy. I do think that jumping in and trying to quantify differences in even an arbitrary way is helpful to see the landscape of problems. I can suggest some data sets (both numerically verified and physically obtained) to start from.

content.raw:
That sounds good up to the point of computing a diff, which I feel won't be very useful for validation (see Evan's comment above as well). Here are a number of reasons why:

1. Simulation mimics reality up to a point. We currently can't expect the output of simulation to match reality. However, we can expect the high-level behavior (robot takes 5 steps and roughly travels 1meter) to be good.

2. We can't use precise diffs in our integration tests due to differences between computers, drivers, changes to underlying libraries, etc. We can use coarse grained comparisons. Applying the concept of diffs to a more complex system seems prone to error and ambiguities.

3. Evan has gone down the road of validating a robot. It required a precise vicon system, months of setup, a highly controlled environment, a very accurate simulation environment, and a simple robot (a ball with an offset motor). Unless we have this kind of requirement, we probably can't expect diffs to work well.

May I make a suggestion? We can have three types of validation:

1. Physics validation (box sliding, ball falling, pendulum). In these cases we can assume that the test environment has been equipped with measurement devices, and a metric comparison would be meaningful.

2. Sensor validation. In these cases a user defines a sensor and a comparison function (line detection algorithm, colored blob finder). Depending on the type of sensor and function, a qualitative and/or quantitative comparison can be performed.

3. Robot validation. In these cases a user defines properties the want to compare (distance traveled, robot opens door). A robot model, simulation environment, and robot controller are required. A qualitative comparison between the real world and simulation can be performed.

It might be worthwhile to discuss and brainstorm about this in person.
content.html:
That sounds good up to the point of computing a diff, which I feel won't be very useful for validation (see Evan's comment above as well). Here are a number of reasons why:

  1. Simulation mimics reality up to a point. We currently can't expect the output of simulation to match reality. However, we can expect the high-level behavior (robot takes 5 steps and roughly travels 1meter) to be good.

  2. We can't use precise diffs in our integration tests due to differences between computers, drivers, changes to underlying libraries, etc. We can use coarse grained comparisons. Applying the concept of diffs to a more complex system seems prone to error and ambiguities.

  3. Evan has gone down the road of validating a robot. It required a precise vicon system, months of setup, a highly controlled environment, a very accurate simulation environment, and a simple robot (a ball with an offset motor). Unless we have this kind of requirement, we probably can't expect diffs to work well.

May I make a suggestion? We can have three types of validation:

  1. Physics validation (box sliding, ball falling, pendulum). In these cases we can assume that the test environment has been equipped with measurement devices, and a metric comparison would be meaningful.

  2. Sensor validation. In these cases a user defines a sensor and a comparison function (line detection algorithm, colored blob finder). Depending on the type of sensor and function, a qualitative and/or quantitative comparison can be performed.

  3. Robot validation. In these cases a user defines properties the want to compare (distance traveled, robot opens door). A robot model, simulation environment, and robot controller are required. A qualitative comparison between the real world and simulation can be performed.

It might be worthwhile to discuss and brainstorm about this in person.

content.raw:
A controller function must be provided to validate a controlled system.

The reason this says "optional" is because the simulation validation tool could be used to validate uncontrolled systems, like a box falling from a fixed height.
content.html:
A controller function must be provided to validate a controlled system.

The reason this says "optional" is because the simulation validation tool could be used to validate uncontrolled systems, like a box falling from a fixed height.

content.raw:
the diff of camera images could be computed with a pixel-by-pixel comparison (using the squared norm in RGB space, for instance). I'm not saying it's a great diff, but it's possible.

I think the idea behind comparing diffs of sensor data is to compare relative runs of the simulation with different parameters.

Also, saying "sensor data" might be confusing here because it's probably more useful, when validating robot kinematics, to compare robot state data (such as joint angles). so when I say sensor data in this document, I also mean the robot's own reading of its joint data. "Sensor data" usually implies visual or depth information, which probably isn't that useful to validate.

Let me try to restate the process in a more concrete way:

The user has two data sets, one of joint commands, the other of actual joint angles collected from the real robot.
The user validates the data set by commanding the same joint trajectories in Gazebo and collecting simulated joint data.
The tool computes a diff and statistics on the diff. for example, for each entry in the joint state vector, an error statistic is computed.
This error statistic is largely useless by itself. However, the user could look at which joints have high error (for example, the elbow of a robot arm has more error that the wrist) and then tune the PID parameters in SDF for the arm in Gazebo.
Then the user runs the process again to see if the error for the joint controlled by the changed parameters is lower.

how does this sound to you?
content.html:
the diff of camera images could be computed with a pixel-by-pixel comparison (using the squared norm in RGB space, for instance). I'm not saying it's a great diff, but it's possible.

I think the idea behind comparing diffs of sensor data is to compare relative runs of the simulation with different parameters.

Also, saying "sensor data" might be confusing here because it's probably more useful, when validating robot kinematics, to compare robot state data (such as joint angles). so when I say sensor data in this document, I also mean the robot's own reading of its joint data. "Sensor data" usually implies visual or depth information, which probably isn't that useful to validate.

Let me try to restate the process in a more concrete way:

The user has two data sets, one of joint commands, the other of actual joint angles collected from the real robot. The user validates the data set by commanding the same joint trajectories in Gazebo and collecting simulated joint data. The tool computes a diff and statistics on the diff. for example, for each entry in the joint state vector, an error statistic is computed. This error statistic is largely useless by itself. However, the user could look at which joints have high error (for example, the elbow of a robot arm has more error that the wrist) and then tune the PID parameters in SDF for the arm in Gazebo. Then the user runs the process again to see if the error for the joint controlled by the changed parameters is lower.

how does this sound to you?

content.raw: I might be misinterpreting your intentions here.
content.html: I might be misinterpreting your intentions here.

content.raw:
A diff of sensor data will most likely offer minimal insight. For example, what would the diff of camera images be? Raw sensor data could varying quite a lot between the real world and simulation, but the overall behavior could be the same.

Unless the real world test environment is rigorously controlled and accurately modeled in simulation, I don't think we can perform validation on raw sensor data. As a starting point, we should look at the overall system behavior. Steve's idea about comparing video would be good, and plotting would be useful to visualize and analyze important values.
content.html:
A diff of sensor data will most likely offer minimal insight. For example, what would the diff of camera images be? Raw sensor data could varying quite a lot between the real world and simulation, but the overall behavior could be the same.

Unless the real world test environment is rigorously controlled and accurately modeled in simulation, I don't think we can perform validation on raw sensor data. As a starting point, we should look at the overall system behavior. Steve's idea about comparing video would be good, and plotting would be useful to visualize and analyze important values.

content.raw: It seems that a controller must be provided, correct? A time series of joint states could be used to validate extrinsic sensors (cameras and lasers), but wouldn't be useful for validating the model itself or intrinsic sensors.
content.html: It seems that a controller must be provided, correct? A time series of joint states could be used to validate extrinsic sensors (cameras and lasers), but wouldn't be useful for validating the model itself or intrinsic sensors.

content.raw:
In the context of simulations in general, validation is often performed qualitatively on a scenario-specific basis ("Does the simulation represent the essential aspects of the physical system?")  

The kind of tool that you are investigating is going to have to be a metric-based approach. In the absence of better information, the metric of minimum (signed) change in work necessary to move from one configuration to another is a reasonable first choice.
content.html:
In the context of simulations in general, validation is often performed qualitatively on a scenario-specific basis ("Does the simulation represent the essential aspects of the physical system?")

The kind of tool that you are investigating is going to have to be a metric-based approach. In the absence of better information, the metric of minimum (signed) change in work necessary to move from one configuration to another is a reasonable first choice.

content.raw: yeah, cool idea but the problem of projecting the 2D video feed over Gazebo sounds like a lot of work, as well as syncing the video to samples
content.html: yeah, cool idea but the problem of projecting the 2D video feed over Gazebo sounds like a lot of work, as well as syncing the video to samples

content.raw: Tagging a few people who could lend their expertise to the design process for this tool: @drum, @sherm1
content.html: Tagging a few people who could lend their expertise to the design process for this tool: @drum, @sherm1

content.raw: visually it will probably help identify some problems, e.g. pose and motion of objects, but only provides qualitative feedback. Note that there will be reprojection errors when virtual models are overlaid on the the video so it could add noise to the results that are measured.
content.html: visually it will probably help identify some problems, e.g. pose and motion of objects, but only provides qualitative feedback. Note that there will be reprojection errors when virtual models are overlaid on the the video so it could add noise to the results that are measured.

content.raw:
What about comparing video of an experiment with animation? Or overlaying animation over a video (kinda crazy, but @iche033 did this in grad school I think).

Not necessary, just a 3am idea
content.html:
What about comparing video of an experiment with animation? Or overlaying animation over a video (kinda crazy, but @iche033 did this in grad school I think).

Not necessary, just a 3am idea

content.raw:
What do you mean by "joint commands will directly control the state of Gazebo joints" ?
My intuition is that there will be a PID (such as the one implemented in `JointController`) that controls the position of the simulated joints, and its desired 
values are the joint positions measured on the real platform, but I don't know if I got it right.
content.html: What do you mean by "joint commands will directly control the state of Gazebo joints" ? My intuition is that there will be a PID (such as the one implemented in JointController) that controls the position of the simulated joints, and its desired values are the joint positions measured on the real platform, but I don't know if I got it right.

We would like to have this tool stable and ready to be used by October so it can collect data for a HAPTIX milestone in November.
